title: Collision between two spheres on strings

content.description:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Spheres <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> have masses <math alttext="m sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="m sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, respectively. Both spheres are suspended from the ceiling by strings of identical lengths. Sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is pulled back so that there is tension in the string and the center of Sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is a vertical distance <math alttext="uppercase H" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math> above the center of Sphere <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is released and then collides with and sticks to Sphere <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The two spheres continue to swing forward, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and momentarily come to rest when the center of mass of the two-sphere system is a height <math alttext="lowercase h sub center of mass" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>h</mi><mtext>CM</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> above the original height of the center of Sphere <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>.
content.question: (a) If the mass of Sphere <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is increased, does <math alttext="lowercase h sub center of mass" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>h</mi><mtext>CM</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> increase, decrease, or remain the same? Justify your answer using appropriate physics principles and qualitative reasoning beyond referencing equations.

Describe the relative masses of spheres <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> that will result in the smallest <math alttext="lowercase h sub center of mass" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>h</mi><mtext>CM</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. Justify your answer using your derivation from part (b).
